Any—-and they are but few—who are well disposed to the king, are unanimous in wishing that the matter should be put in Pompey’s hands, while the. Senate accepts the fictitious plea of religious scruples, not for any reason of religion, but it is jealous of Pompey, and disgusted at the king’s lavish bribery.

As regards Pompey, Ι never cease urging and im- 2 ploring him——nay even frankly rebuking him, and warning him, not to incur a storm of public obloquy ; but he has left absolutely no room for any entreaties or admonitions of mine ; both in his ordinary con- versation, and publicly in the Senate he has advocated your cause with as much eloquence, earnestness, enthusiasm, and energy as anybody could possibly have done, while testifying at the same time in the highest terms to your good offiees towards him and his own affection for you.
